advanced_h.intro_Txt: This page provides access to the advanced image settings for this device.
advanced_h.captureModeTxt01: Capture mode - The capture mode setting reduces image flicker in fluorescent light environments and is set the first time the product is accessed. Changing capture mode is not recommended as most video stream settings will either be removed or reset.
advanced_h.captureModeTxt02: To reduce image flicker, select the capture mode with the power line frequency (50 Hz or 60 Hz) used at the location of the Axis product. When using 50 Hz, the maximum frame rate is limited to 25 fps.
advanced_h.captureModeTxt03: Capture mode - Capture mode defines the maximum resolution and maximum frame rate available in the Axis product. The capture mode setting also affects the camera's angle of view, if using a capture mode with a smaller maximum resolution, the angle of view is reduced.
advanced_h.captureModeTxt04a: Note: The Capture mode is set the first time the product is accessed.
advanced_h.captureModeTxt04b: Changing capture mode is not recommended as most other settings will be either removed or reset to default, for example:
advanced_h.viewAreaTxt1: Check this box to enable the ability to define specific areas of the overview image called view areas. To set up a view area go to Video & Audio > View Area.
advanced_h.viewAreaTxt2: Check this box to enable the ability to define specific areas of the overview image called view areas, that are treated as different video sources. To set up a view area go to Video & Audio > View Areas.
advanced_h.viewAreaOpticNote: Note: View Areas is not available when Optical Live Zoom is selected as a PTZ mode.
advanced_h.viewAreaUploadableDrNote: Note: View Areas is not available when Uploadable PTZ driver is selected as a PTZ mode.
advanced_h.CamOriHelpTxt: To change the camera's orientation, go to Setup > System Options > Maintenance and click the Restore button. Note that all except IP parameters will be reset to original settings. After restore, the product will present an initial screen, select the required orientation from the list.
advanced_h.colorLTxt: Color level - Lower values mean less color saturation, while the value 100 gives maximum color saturation. The value 0 gives a black and white image.
advanced_h.brightTxt: Brightness - This slidebar adjusts the image brightness, where a higher value produces a brighter image.
advanced_h.shrpTxt1: Sharpness - Controls the amount of sharpening applied to the image.
advanced_h.shrpTxt2: In general, a higher setting will improve the image's sharpness, but at the expense of increased image noise, especially in low light conditions. There may also be image artifacts present around areas with high contrast (e.g. sharp edges).
advanced_h.shrpTxt3: A lower setting reduces the amount of image noise, but makes the image less sharp.
advanced_h.contrTxt: Contrast - This slidebar adjusts the image's contrast, where a higher value produces an image with high contrast between dark and light areas.
advanced_h.localContrTxt: Local contrast - Applies contrast to a specific area of the image. Use the slidebar to adjust the image's contrast, where a higher value produces an image with high contrast between dark and light areas.
advanced_h.barrelDistCorrTxt: Barrel distortion correction - Provides an option to correct or disable the barrel distortion. Select Custom from the drop-down list and click Edit to launch the barrel distortion correction page.
advanced_h.iRCF_Txt1: IR cut filter - Set this filter to Off to allow the camera to 'see' infrared light, e.g. at night, and/or when using an infrared lamp. This makes the image clearer.
advanced_h.iRCF_auto_note_Txt1: If set to Auto, the camera will automatically switch between IR cut filter On and Off, according to the current lighting conditions.
advanced_h.iRCF_dome_note_Txt1: This is only possible when the iris is set to Auto Iris, and the exposure control is set to Automatic.
advanced_h.iRlamp_Txt1: Setting the IR cut filter to OFF will also enable the buttons controlling the IR lamp. Set the lamp to ON or OFF as required.
advanced_h.imgCorrOffTxt: Off - select off to disable image correction.
advanced_h.electrImgStabTxt: Electronic image stabilization (EIS) - When monitoring an environment that is subject to vibrations e.g. train station or traffic control, images may appear to be unsteady.
advanced_h.autoElectrImgStabTxt: To automatically improve image stability, check the Electronic image stabilization (EIS) box.
advanced_h.mannElectrImgStabTxt: To improve image stability, manually adjust focus and zoom and note the approximate focal length value as indicated in the camera unit below the zoom puller. Check the Electronic image stabilization (EIS) box and use the slider to adjust the focal length to match the focal length value previously set manually to get the best image stability. Open the Live view page on another window and observe how the image stabilizes after adjusting the slider and saving.
advanced_h.electrImgStabNoteTxt: Note: The focal length values (Micrometer) available depends on the selected optics.
advanced_h.whitebal_Txt1: This adjusts the relative amount of red, green and blue primary colors in the image so that the neutral colors are reproduced correctly.
advanced_h.whitebal_Txt2: The camera can be set to automatically adjust for the type of light and compensate for its color.
advanced_h.whitebal_man_Txt: Alternatively, the type of light source can be set manually.
advanced_h.options_Txt: From the drop-down list, select the white balance setting suitable for the lighting used for your camera. The available options are:
advanced_h.other_fixedin_Txt1: Fixed Indoor - Fixed color adjustment, ideal for a room with some artificial light other than fluorescent lighting and good for normal light temperatures at around 2600K.
advanced_h.other_fixedfluor1_Txt1: Fixed Fluorescent 1 - Fixed color adjustment; good for fluorescent lighting with color temperatures at around 4000K.
advanced_h.other_fixedfluor2_Txt1: Fixed Fluorescent 2 - Fixed color adjustment; good for fluorescent lighting with color temperatures at around 5000K.
advanced_h.other_fixedout1_Txt1: Fixed Outdoor 1 - Fixed color adjustment. Good for sky light in bright conditions, for color temperatures at around 5500K.
advanced_h.other_fixedout2_Txt1: Fixed Outdoor 2 - Fixed color adjustment. Good for sky light in less bright conditions, for color temperatures at around 6500K.
advanced_h.other_auto_Txt1: Automatic - Automatic identification and compensation for the light source color. This can be used in most situations and is the recommended setting.
advanced_h.street_auto_Txt: Automatic Outdoor - Automatic color adjustment for outdoors. It allows images to be captured in natural white balance in morning and evening light.
advanced_h.auto_sodium_Txt: Automatic Sodium - Automatic color adjustment that compensates for the yellow orange color of sodium vapor lights common in street lighting.
advanced_h.street_sodium_Txt1: Street lighting - Sodium - Automatic color adjustment that compensates for the yellow orange color of sodium vapor lights common in street lighting.
advanced_h.other_hold_Txt1: Hold Current - Fixes the white balance at its current state. As an aid when doing this - open 2 browser windows - one showing the live image and one showing these settings.
advanced_h.other_hold_Txt2: Set the White balance to Automatic
advanced_h.other_hold_Txt3: Position the camera so that most of the image is filled by the object that should be neutral (white/grey) and then allow the camera to automatically adjust
advanced_h.other_hold_Txt4: Set to Hold Current when the image meets requirements.
advanced_h.dome_Txt1: Auto - Automatic identification and compensation for the light source color. This can be used in most situations and is the recommended setting.
advanced_h.dome_Txt2: Fixed Indoor - Fixed color adjustment, ideal for a room with some artificial light other than fluorescent lighting and good for normal light temperatures at around 3200K.
advanced_h.dome_Txt3: Indoor bulb - Fixed color adjustment; ideal for a room with artificial light other than fluorescent lighting; e.g. for areas illuminated using standard light bulbs. Good for normal light temperatures up to 3200K
advanced_h.dome_Txt4: Fixed Outdoor - Fixed color adjustment. Good for sky light in bright conditions, for color temperatures at around 5800K.
advanced_h.street_sodium_Txt2: Street lighting - Sodium - Automatic color adjustment that compensates for the yellow orange color of sodium vapor lights common in street lighting.
advanced_h.street_mercury_Txt1: Street lighting - Mercury - Automatic color adjustment for the mercury vapor lights common in street lighting.
advanced_h.imgh_whitebalance2_Txt1: Automatic - Automatic identification and compensation for the light source color. This can be used in most situations and is the recommended setting.
advanced_h.imgh_whitebalance2_Txt2: Automatic - wide - Use this setting for automatic compensation in difficult lighting conditions, when the standard automatic setting is not enough. This may be useful when compensating for e.g. the lighting conditions commonly found around dawn and dusk.
advanced_h.imgh_whitebalance2_Txt3: Fixed Indoor - Fixed color adjustment, ideal for a room with some artificial light other than fluorescent lighting and good for normal light temperatures at around 2600K.
advanced_h.imgh_whitebalance2_Txt4: Fixed Outdoor - Fixed color adjustment. Good for sky light in bright conditions, for color temperatures at around 5500K.
advanced_h.imgh_whitebalance2_Txt5: Fixed Fluorescent - Fixed color adjustment; good for fluorescent lighting with color temperatures at around 4000K.
advanced_h.street_sodium_Txt3: Street lighting - Sodium - Automatic color adjustment that compensates for the yellow orange color of sodium vapor lights common in street lighting.
advanced_h.street_mercury_Txt2: Street lighting - Mercury - Automatic color adjustment for the mercury vapor lights common in street lighting.
advanced_h.other_auto_Txt2: Automatic - Automatic identification and compensation for the light source color. This can be used in most situations and is the recommended setting.
advanced_h.other_auto_cont1: This option enables the White balance window drop-down list.
advanced_h.other_auto_outTxt: Automatic Outdoor - Automatic color adjustment that compensates for typical outdoor lighting such as the yellow orange color of sodium vapor lights common in street lighting or the color caused by light reflected in snow.
advanced_h.other_auto_cont2: This option enables the White balance window drop-down list.
advanced_h.other_auto_wideTxt: Automatic - wide - Use this setting for automatic compensation in difficult lighting conditions, when the standard automatic setting is not enough. This may be useful when compensating for e.g. the lighting conditions commonly found around dawn and dusk.
advanced_h.other_hold_Txt5: Hold Current - Fixes the white balance at its current state.
advanced_h.other_fixedout1_Txt2: Fixed Outdoor 1 - Fixed color adjustment for sunny, with a color temperature around 5500K.
advanced_h.other_fixedout2_Txt2: Fixed Outdoor 2 - Fixed color adjustment for cloudy, with a color temperature around 6500K.
advanced_h.other_fixedin_Txt2: Fixed Indoor - Fixed color adjustment, ideal for a room with some artificial light other than fluorescent lighting and good for a normal color temperature around 2800K.
advanced_h.other_fixedfluor1_Txt2: Fixed Fluorescent 1 - Fixed color adjustment; good for fluorescent lighting with a color temperature around 4000K.
advanced_h.other_fixedfluor2_Txt2: Fixed Fluorescent 2 - Fixed color adjustment; good for fluorescent lighting with a color temperature around 3000K.
advanced_h.other_manual_Txt: Manual - Select this option and click Edit to manually set a reference point for the white balance in the View area.
advanced_h.street_sodium_Txt4: Street lighting - Sodium - Automatic color adjustment that compensates for the yellow orange color of sodium vapor lights common in street lighting.
advanced_h.street_mercury_Txt3: Street lighting - Mercury - Automatic color adjustment for the mercury vapor lights common in street lighting.
advanced_h.whitebal_notes_Txt2: The automatic white balance setting reduces the risk of color flicker by adapting to changes gradually. When changing the lighting, or when the camera is first powered up, it can take up to 30 seconds to lock on to the new light source.
advanced_h.whitebal_notes_Txt3: If a scene is illuminated by more than one type of light source, i.e. they differ in color temperature, the dominating light source will act as a reference for the automatic white balance algorithm. This behavior can be overridden by choosing a fixed white balance setting that matches the light source you want to use as a reference.
advanced_h.white_balance_window1: White balance window - The white balance window is enabled for the Automatic and Automatic outdoor options set in the White balance drop-down list. Select one of the options below from the drop-down list to set the white balance window properties.
advanced_h.white_balance_window2: Automatic - Select this option to use the default settings for the Automatic and Automatic outdoor options, set in the White balance drop-down list.
advanced_h.white_balance_window3: Custom - Select this option to manually set a reference window for the white balance in the view area.
advanced_h.wdrTxt1: WDR - Dynamic Capture - Select On from the drop-down list to enable Dynamic Capture. This option improves the exposure when there is a considerable contrast between light and dark areas in an image.
advanced_h.wdrTxt1-1: WDR - Dynamic Capture - Wide Dynamic Range can improve the exposure when there is a considerable contrast between light and dark areas in an image.
advanced_h.wdrForeCaptTxt: WDR - Forensic Capture - Wide Dynamic Range can improve the exposure when there is a considerable contrast between light and dark areas in an image.
advanced_h.wdrTxt4: WDR On - Select WDR On to enable Wide Dynamic Range (WDR). WDR may be used in monitoring dark and bright areas. It is adviced to use WDR Mode in bright conditions for example when monitoring cars, because WDR Mode handles the headlights well therefore performing better compared to Lightfinder Mode.
advanced_h.wdrTxt4_noLightfinderTxt: WDR On - Select WDR On to enable Wide Dynamic Range (WDR). WDR may be used in monitoring dark and bright areas. It is adviced to use WDR Mode in bright conditions for example when monitoring cars, because WDR Mode handles the headlights well therefore performing better compared to when WDR is Off.
advanced_h.wdrOffTxt: WDR Off - Select this option to disable Wide Dynamic Range.
advanced_h.wdrTxt5: Lightfinder Mode - Select this option to switch to Lightfinder Mode. By selecting Lightfinder Mode, the product will be optimized for low light conditions in order to give a better image quality. Lightfinder Mode may be used in a variety of low light applications such as parking lots, city surveilance and construction sites.
advanced_h.wdrTxt2: Note: Dynamic Capture is only possible when the Exposure control setting is set to Automatic.
advanced_h.wdrTxt2-1: Dynamic Capture is only possible when the Exposure control setting is set to Automatic.
advanced_h.wdrForeCaptNoteTxt: Forensic Capture is only possible when the Exposure control setting is set to Automatic.
advanced_h.wdrCaptureMode_noteTxt: Note: The WDR On and Lightfinder Mode options are only available when Capture mode is set to 720p @ 25/30 fps.
advanced_h.wdrCaptureMode_noteTxt-1: The WDR On and Lightfinder Mode options are only available when Capture mode is set to 720p @ 25/30 fps.
advanced_h.wdrSpecFeatures_noteTxt: Note: Functionalities such as Exposure value, Exposure zones, Backlight compensation and Shutter & Gain's Normal Light are not available when WDR is On or when the selected Capture mode has WDR enabled.
advanced_h.wdrSpecFeatures_noteTxt-1: Functionalities such as Exposure value, Exposure zones, Backlight compensation and Shutter & Gain's Normal Light are not available when WDR is On or when the selected Capture mode has WDR enabled.
advanced_h.highlightsRecovery_Txt: Highlights recovery - Improves the image appearance by decreasing brightness to the bright parts of the image. Use the slidebar to adjust the highlight recovery where, a high value reduces the brightness in the image.
advanced_h.shadowsRecovery_Txt: Shadows recovery - Improves the image appearance by increasing brightness to the dark parts of the image. Use the slidebar to adjust the shadow recovery where, a high value increases the brightness in the image.
advanced_h.dcTxt1: Enable Dynamic Contrast - This option improves the exposure when there is a considerable contrast between light and dark areas in an image. Use the slidebar to adjust dynamic contrast, where high applies more dynamic contrast to the image. The scene may affect how the changes to an image are seen when adjusting dynamic contrast.
advanced_h.dcTxt2: Note: Dynamic contrast is only possible when the Exposure control setting is set to Automatic.
advanced_h.wdrTxt3: Wide dynamic range: Wide dynamic range can improve the exposure when there is a considerable contrast between light and dark areas in the image. Enable WDR in intense backlight conditions. The different WDR settings adjust for various amounts of contrast in the image. Use a higher WDR number for a higher contrast. Disable WDR in low light conditions for optimal exposure.
advanced_h.trafficmodeTxt: Traffic Light Mode - This mode will modify the exposure settings, so that traffic lights and other bright light sources will not saturate when in view at night. In this mode, it is possible to distinguish the color of the traffic light at any surrounding light level.
advanced_h.trafficmodeNoteTxt1: Note: The decrease in exposure will make the whole image darker, during conditions above.
advanced_h.trafficmodeNoteTxt2: Note: This setting will disable the Exposure Settings for best results.
advanced_h.rotQTxt: Enable Backlight compensation - Backlight compensation makes the subject appear clearer when the image background is too bright, or the subject is too dark.
advanced_h.expcont_Txt1: Exposure control - This setting can be used to adapt to the amount/type of light being used. The available settings are:
advanced_h.expcont_Txt2: Auto - This setting is the default and can be used in most situations. The shutter speed, iris and gain are automatically set to produce optimum image quality.
advanced_h.expcont_Txt3: Manual Shutter - This allows you to manually adjust the shutter speed. A slower speed in dark conditions will help to produce a brighter image, but will produce fewer frames per second, which may cause blurry images during motion.
advanced_h.expcont_Txt4: Manual Iris - This allows you to manually adjust the iris opening in the lens. A larger F value means less light sensitivity, but a larger depth of field.
advanced_h.expcont_Txt5: Manual - If you have special requirements for the exposure setting and wish to lock it, select this option. Select the desired Shutter speed, Iris f-number and Gain from the drop-down lists.
advanced_h.expcont_Txt6: Measured in decibels (dB), Gain describes the amount of amplification applied to a signal, in this case the visual information in the image. Although it is possible to attain a high level of amplification, and thereby provide viewable images in very low light, high gain levels will also increase the amount of image noise.
advanced_h.expcont_Txt7: Note - Backlight compensation and IR cut filter in auto mode is only possible when the Exposure control is set to Auto
advanced_h.max_exp_Txt1: Max exposure time - Increasing the exposure time will improve image quality, but there may be an increase in motion blur.
advanced_h.viewsetTxt1: To view the video stream with the current configuration, click first Save and then View. A pop-up window appears showing the current video stream configuration.
advanced_h.expcont_Txt8: Exposure control - This setting can be used to adapt to the amount/type of light being used.
advanced_h.expcont_settings_domeTxt1: Automatic - This setting is the default and can be used in most situations. The maximum exposure time is automatically set to produce optimum image quality.
advanced_h.expcont_settings_domeTxt2: Note: Checking the box Allow slow shutter will result in a decrease in shutter speed in poor light, which allows more light in and increases the image brightness. This may also result in a drop in the frame rate, as well as blurry images. If full frame rate in all lighting conditions is always required, then this setting should not be enabled.
advanced_h.expcont_settings_domeTxt3: Manual - If you have special requirements for the exposure setting and wish to lock it - select this option. Select the desired exposure time from the drop-down list.
advanced_h.expcont_settings_domeTxt4: Note: that this setting may cause unwanted image effects.
advanced_h.expvTxt: Exposure value - Use this slidebar to fine tune the exposure.
advanced_h.expcontthermal_Txt: Exposure control - This setting is used to adapt to the amount of light being used. For most situations, the Automatic setting can be used. Different settings may show variations in apparent image quality depending on the scene. Linear settings provide the best true thermal image of the scene, but may also increase image noise.
advanced_h.expcont_Txt9: Exposure control - Set to Automatic for optimal exposure settings automatically, for example brightness and noise. Flicker-free 50 or 60 Hz is used to remove flicker which can be caused by fluorescent and other light sources. The Hold current option locks the current exposure settings.
advanced_h.expcont_Txt9-1: Exposure control - Set to Automatic for optimal exposure settings automatically, for example brightness and noise. Flicker-reduced 50 or 60 Hz is used to remove flicker which can be caused by fluorescent and other light sources. The Hold current option locks the current exposure settings.
advanced_h.max_exp_Txt2: Max exposure time - Increasing the exposure time will improve image quality, but at the expense of the total frame rate. There may also be an increase in motion blur.
advanced_h.slow_shutter_Txt: Allow slow shutter - checking this box will result in a decrease in shutter speed in poor light, which allows more light in and increases the image brightness. This may also result in a drop in the frame rate, as well as blurry images. Do not enable this if full frame rate in all lighting conditions is always required.
advanced_h.backlightTxt1: Enable Backlight compensation - Backlight compensation makes the subject appear clearer when the image background is too bright, or the subject is too dark.
advanced_h.backlightTxt2: Enable Backlight compensation - Backlight compensation makes the subject appear clearer when the image background is too bright, or the subject is too dark.
advanced_h.expcont_settings_area3_Txt: Exposure zones - This setting determines which part of the image will be used to calculate the exposure. The Auto setting can be used in many situations, but for particular requirements, select one of the other predefined areas.
advanced_h.expcont_settings_area1_Txt: Exposure zones - This setting determines which part of the image will be used to calculate the exposure. The Auto setting can be used in most situations, but for particular requirements, select Defined and click the Edit button to open the Exposure Windows dialog to custom define the exposure zone.
advanced_h.expcont_settings_area1Note_Txt: Note: When using custom exposure zones, other parts of the image may exhibit poor image quality due to saturation.
advanced_h.expcont_settings_area2_Txt1: Exposure zones - This setting determines which part of the image will be used to calculate the exposure. The Auto setting can be used in many situations, but for particular requirements, select one of the other predefined areas.
advanced_h.expcont_settings_area2_Txt2: Selecting a predefined exposure area will show (as percentages) how each part of the image will be used to calculate the exposure. Note that a percentage value does not reflect the size of that area, but is instead an indication of how much 'weight' is given to that area when calculating the exposure.
advanced_h.expcont_settings_gainThermal_Txt: Gain - This defines the amount of amplification applied to a signal, in this case the visual information in the image. Although it is possible to attain a high level of amplification, and thereby providing better detail in the images, high gain levels will also increase the amount of image noise. Lowering the gain reduces image noise but can result in a darker image.
advanced_h.iRCF_Txt2: IR cut filter - Set this filter to Off to allow the camera to 'see' infrared light, e.g. at night, and/or when using an infrared lamp. This makes the image clearer.
advanced_h.iRCF_auto_note_Txt2: If set to Auto, the camera will automatically switch between IR cut filter On and Off, according to the current lighting conditions.
advanced_h.iRCF_dome_note_Txt2: This is only possible when the iris is set to Auto Iris, and the exposure control is set to Automatic.
advanced_h.iRlamp_Txt2: Setting the IR cut filter to OFF will also enable the buttons controlling the IR lamp. Set the lamp to ON or OFF as required.
advanced_h.shutter_gain1: Shutter and Gain - The Shutter and Gain drop-down lists can be configured in four ways:
advanced_h.shutter_gain2: Shutter=Auto, Gain=Auto - This configuration enables the possibilty to manually set the priority between low noise and low motion blur for both low light and normal light. It also allows the user to set the maximum value for shutter time in low light and the maximum values for gain in both normal light and low light.
advanced_h.shutter_gain3: Shutter=Fixed, Gain=Auto - This configuration enables the possibilty to set a fixed value for the shutter time and a maximum value for the gain, allowing the camera to automatically set the gain depending on brightness.
advanced_h.shutter_gain4: Shutter=Auto, Gain=Fixed - This configuration enables the possibilty to set a fixed value for the gain and a maximum value for the shutter time, allowing the camera to automatically set the shutter time depending on brightness.
advanced_h.shutter_gain5: Shutter=Fixed, Gain=Fixed - This configuration enables the possibilty to set a fixed value for the shutter and the gain.
advanced_h.shutter_gain_notes2: Shutter - A smaller value means less motion blur, but requires a well lit scene. A larger value will allow more light in the camera so that even a low lit scene can produce a good image, but at the expense of increased motion blur.
advanced_h.shutter_gain_notes3: Gain - A lower value means less noise, but which can in dark situations lead to a very dark image. A larger value means more amplification making it possible to observe a dark scene, but with increased noise and an increased bandwidth usage.
advanced_h.priority_normal_light1: Priority - Use the slide bar to set the priority between Low motion blur and Low noise in the normal light area (see
advanced_h.priority_normal_light2: When prioritizing low noise (slide bar all the way to the left) the camera will automatically decrease shutter speed as brightness decreases. When the shutter speed reaches 1/30 s the camera will increase gain until the set maximum gain for normal light is reached. This is the default priority setting for normal light.
advanced_h.max_gain_normal_light: Max gain - Select a value from the drop-down list. This defines the upper limit of the normal light area.
advanced_h.max_fastShutterNormalLight: Max fast shutter - Sets shutter speed limit in normal light condition. Depending on a scenario, the shutter speed limit may need to be set, this is done through System Options > Advanced > Plain Config.
advanced_h.priority_low_light1: Priority - Use the slide bar to set the priority between Low motion blur and Low noise in the low light area (see
advanced_h.priority_low_light3: When prioritizing low motion blur (slide bar all the way to the right) the camera will automatically increase gain as brightness decreases. When the gain reaches the set maximum gain for low light the camera will decrease shutter speed until the set maximum shutter for low light is reached. This is the default priority setting for low light.
advanced_h.max_gain_low_light: Max gain - Select a value from the drop-down list. This defines the upper limit of the low light area.
advanced_h.max_shutter_low_light: Max shutter - Select a value from the drop-down list. This defines the right limit of the low light area.
advanced_h.exposurepriority_Txt: Exposure priority - This defines the balance between image quality and the frame rate. When Motion is prioritized, motion blur is minimized, but the image quality may be reduced with a higher frame rate. A prioritized Low noise will provide better image quality with a lower frame rate.
advanced_h.shutter_Txt: Shutter - A smaller value means less motion blur, but requires a well lit scene. A larger value will allow more light in the camera so that even a low lit scene can produce a good image, but at the expense of increased motion blur. When using Flicker-free 50 Hz the shortest shutter time is 1/100 s, and when using Flicker-free 60 Hz the shortest shutter time is 1/120 s. This setting is only available when the Exposure priority is set to Motion or Low noise.
advanced_h.gain_Txt1: Gain - A lower value means less noise, but which can in dark situations lead to a very dark image. A larger value means more amplification making it possible to observe a dark scene, but with increased noise. This setting is only available when the Exposure priority is set to Motion or Low noise.
advanced_h.gain_Txt2: When motion is prioritized the shutter time is kept as low as possible. When low noise is prioritized the gain is kept as low as possible.
advanced_h.gain_Txt3: Setting min/max to the same values is equivalent to setting a fixed value.
advanced_h.expcont_settings_irisMngr_Txt: Iris configuration - This field displays the current configured iris type. To change iris configuration, click Edit....
advanced_h.expcont_settings_DCiris_Txt: Enable automatic iris adjustment - This should always be set to Enabled, except during focusing, or when using a fixed iris lens.
advanced_h.expcont_settings_positionable_Txt1: Iris adjustment - Set the preferred F value, with this slide bar. When the option Enable automatic iris adjustment is enabled, the precise iris will use this value as long as light conditions are favorable for the setting, otherwise it will adjust itself to the best iris setting. If the automatic iris adjustment is NOT enabled, the precise iris will lock on this setting regardless of light conditions.
advanced_h.expcont_settings_positionable_Txt2: The number scale represents the amount the iris is open. When the scale is set at 0 the iris is opened as much as allowed. At the setting 100 the iris is closed as much as allowed. The default setting is 50. The actual F value is shown under the Iris adjustment bar
advanced_h.max_gain_Txt: Max gain - Measured in decibels (dB), gain describes the amount of amplification applied to a signal, in this case the visual information in the image. Although it is possible to attain a high level of amplification, thus providing viewable images in very low light, high gain levels will also increase the amount of image noise.
advanced_h.highLightCompensation_Txt: Highlight Compensation - The Axis product will detect a bright light from a source such as a torch or car headlights and mask that image area. This setting is useful when the camera operates in a very dark area where a bright light may overexpose part of the image and prevent the operator from seeing other parts of the scene.
advanced_h.highLightCompensation1_Txt: Adjust the sensitivity by selecting the options from the highlight compensation drop-down list.High means that the Axis product will apply a maximum masking and Low means the product will apply very little mask to the over exposed part of the image.
advanced_h.highLightCompensation_Txt-1: Enable Highlight Compensation - The Axis product will detect a bright light from a source such as a torch or car headlights and mask that image area. This setting is useful when the camera operates in a very dark area where a bright light may overexpose part of the image and prevent the operator from seeing other parts of the scene. To enable highlight compensation, check the box Enable Highlight Compensation.
advanced_h.highLightCompensation2_Txt: Adjust the color of the mask by selecting the options from the Mask tone drop-down list.
advanced_h.autofocus_Txt: Autofocus enabled - Check this box to enable the camera's automatic focusing function. This setting is enabled by default.
advanced_h.autodefog_Txt: Auto defog - The Axis product will detect the fog effect and automatically remove it to get a clear image. Select the level of fog removal from the drop-down list. High implies that maximum fog removal is applied while Off implies that no fog removal will be applied.
advanced_h.autodefogNote_Txt: Note: Auto defog can be activated incorrectly especially in scenes with low contrast, high light level variations or when auto focus is slightly off. This can affect the image quality by for example, increasing image contrast. Also, too much brightness can negatively impact the image quality when defog is active.
advanced_h.noiseREduction_Txt: Noise reduction - Image noise is caused by random brightness or color information that produces a grainy appearance in the image. Check this box to enable the camera's noise reduction function. Note that noise reduction may increase the amount of motion blur.
advanced_h.stabilizer_Txt1: Stabilizer - When monitoring environments that are subject to vibrations (e.g. traffic control), images may appear to be unsteady. Depending on the environment, select the frequency (High or Low) that gives the best improvement in image quality.
advanced_h.stabilizer_Txt2: Note: Enabling the stabilizer will limit the digital zoom to 2x (70x total zoom).
advanced_h.stabilizer_Txt3: Image freeze on PTZ - Use this option to freeze the image while the camera is moving during a pan, tilt or zoom operation. Once the camera reaches its new position, the image from that position is shown.
advanced_h.niViTxt: IR cut filter - Set this filter to Off to allow the camera to 'see' infrared light, for instance at night, and/or when using an infrared lamp. This makes the image clearer. Set to On during daylight or bright light conditions to cut out infrared light which will improve colors in the image. When set to Auto, the camera will automatically switch between On and Off, according to the current lighting conditions.
advanced_h.adv_help_DaNiShLeTxt: Day/Night shift level - This setting can be used to change when the camera shifts into night mode. By default, the camera will automatically change from day to night mode at a pre-defined level which corresponds to level 100 in the slider. By setting this slider to a lower value, the camera will change to night mode earlier.
advanced_h.adv_help_DaNiShPrioSliderTxt: Day/Night shift priority - This slidebar can be used to change when the camera shifts into either day mode or night mode. By default, the camera will automatically change from day to night mode at a pre-defined level which corresponds to light conditions. By dragging the slider knob towards the sun, the camera will change to day mode earlier and change to night mode late.
advanced_h.enFoAdTxt: Enable focus adjustment for IR illumination - The camera lens is IR corrected, which means that it maintains focus in mixed light, however a small focus adjustment is recommended when IR illumination is used. Check this box to automatically adjust the focus when the IR cut filter switches between on and off.
advanced_h.adv_help_EnIrIllTxt: Enable IR illumination - Check this box to enable the built in IR light. The built in IR light can be used for video surveillance in areas with low light, without requiring addition of external lighting. The IR light can be disabled, by unchecking the Enable IR illumination box, this is useful in order to be able to use the Axis product in areas where the use of IR light is forbidden.
advanced_h.adv_help_SyncIrIllTxt: Synchronize IR illumination with day/night - Check this box to synchronize the IR light illumination with Day/Night detection, that is the IR light will automatically be turned on during the night and turned off during the day. Uncheck this box to disable the IR light synchronization with Day/Night. Note that for Axis products with IR cut filter, the filter setting must be Auto or Off, in order for the Day/Night synchronization to work.
advanced_h.adv_help_ConfIrIllTxt: Configure IR illumination: - Click Edit to see advanced settings for configuring IR illumination.
advanced_h.viewsetTxt2: To view the video stream with the current configuration, click first Save and then View. A pop-up window appears showing the current video stream configuration
advanced_h.viewsetTxt3: To view the video stream with the current configuration, click first Save and then View. A pop-up window appears showing the current video stream configuration.

ir_light_settings_h.irLiAreaTxt: The IR illumination window displays the approximate area the IR light will illuminate given the current settings.
ir_light_settings_h.irLiAutoTxt: Auto (follow zoom) - Automatically adjusts the IR illumination according to the camera's zoom information. The angle of view (zoom) will be the same as the angle of illumination. If the camera's angle of view changes, the IR illumination will change with it.
ir_light_settings_h.irLiManualTxt: Manual - Sets the angle of illumination manually. This setting is useful when needed to set the angle of illumination to be different from the camera's angle of view.
ir_light_settings_h.irLiManualExTxt: If the camera has a wide angle of view you can set the angle of illumination to a more tele position. Note that this will result in dark corners in the image, use this setup if for some reasons it fits your installation requirements.
ir_light_settings_h.irLiAngOfIllTxt: Angle of illumination- Use the slider to adjust the angle of illumination. The default IR illumination zoom is set at 1. If the camera's zoom is adjusted to a different value, move the Angle of illumination slider to the same value, for optimal IR illumination in the IR illumination window.
ir_light_settings_h.irLiAngOfIllTxt-1: Angle of illumination- Use the slider to adjust the angle of illumination. If the camera's zoom is adjusted to a different value, move the Angle of illumination slider to the same value, for optimal IR illumination in the IR illumination window.

exposure_windows_h.intro_Txt: Determine which part of the image will be used to calculate the exposure by setting up an exposure window setting.
exposure_windows_h.selWinTxt1: Select window setting - Use the drop-down list to select an area in the image that will be used to calculate the exposure. The Automatic setting can be used in many situations, but if you have particular requirements, select one of the other predefined areas or create a custom area.
exposure_windows_h.selWinTxt2: Selecting a predefined exposure area will show (as a percentage) how each part of the image will be used to calculate the exposure. Note that a percentage value does not reflect the size of that area, but is instead an indication of how much 'weight' is given to that area when calculating the exposure.
exposure_windows_h.custWinTxt1: A custom area can either include or exclude part of the image when calculating the exposure.
exposure_windows_h.custWinTxt9: A custom area can include a part of the image when calculating the exposure.
exposure_windows_h.custWinThermalTxt1: A custom area includes a part of the image to be used when calculating the exposure.
exposure_windows_h.custWinTxt4: Click Add include, and a blue box appears in the image.
exposure_windows_h.custWinTxt5: Using the mouse, click in the box to adjust its size and position to the desired area in the image.
exposure_windows_h.custWinTxt7: To create a window for an area that should not be used for calculating exposure, click Add exclude and follow the instructions above. Click Remove to delete an include or exclude window. Up to 10 custom include and exlude windows can be set up and used at one time.
exposure_windows_h.custWinTxt8: Click Remove to delete an include window. Only one custom include window can be set up and used at one time.
exposure_windows_h.custWinThermalTxt2: To delete an include window, select it and click Remove. Note that, only one exposure window can be set up and used at one time.

one-click_white_balance_h.subTitle: Edit White Balance Point
one-click_white_balance_h.intro_Txt: Drag the small square in the view area to the desired location to define the white balance point. Click OK to save. Click Close to exit.

white_balance_window_h.subTitle: Edit White Balance Window
white_balance_window_h.intro_Txt: Rezise and drag the White balance window in the view area to the desired location to define an area for the white balance. Click OK to save. Click Close to exit.

iris_config_h.intro_Txt: Change the iris configuration for the iris lens installed.
iris_config_h.select_h_Txt: Select which iris is installed - Select the iris lens from the drop-down list which has been installed and click Ok. If the iris lens is not listed, upload the configuration file under the Upload tab.
iris_config_h.upload_h_Txt: Upload a new iris configuration file - If the iris lens is not in the list, then a new iris configuration file is needed. To upload a new configuration, click Browse and select the configuration file which was downloaded from www.axis.com or included with the iris. Click Upload. The installed iris should now be included in the drop-down list under Iris.

barrel_distortion_correction_h.intro_Txt: Barrel distortion makes an image appear curved and bent outwards. This condition is seen more clearly when the image is zoomed out too much. The level of distortion is determined by the zoom level applied on the image.
barrel_distortion_correction_h.intro_Txt1: Correct the barrel distortion effect by using the Correction factor. The image will be cropped and stretched in order to correct distortion.
barrel_distortion_correction_h.correctionFactorTxt: Correction factor: Use the slide bar to modify the barrel distortion values. To correct barrel distortion, slide the bar towards the left until the correction level meets your requirements.
barrel_distortion_correction_h.showGridTxt: Show grid: Select this option to see the grid lines on top of the image. The lines assist when correcting the distortion as they make it easy to see if the corrected image aligns with the grid lines.
